title: The Block 2019 episode 47 and 48 recap: Tess fears for her marriage
text:
Oh, my eyes!

I hope they had a nudity warning for these episodes because — thanks to El’ise — every bloke within cooee of her on The Block was getting his gear off.

It all started when El’ise noticed that her handsome chippie had a huge following on Instagram. Why? Well let’s just say it’s more to do with his chiselled abs than the chiselling he’s paid to do on work sites.

RELATED:

Episode 46 recap: Mitch and Jesse go head to head

Behind the scenes of The Block’s biggest arguments

El’ise then took it upon herself to give foreman Keith some stick for his lacklustre following on social media, hinting that it might be because he has remained fully clothed in all his posts.

“We are supposed to be renovating (not stripping),” a stunned Keith pointed out, before dutifully removing his high-vis vest to strut about half naked with Paul.

It should be noted that even when stripping, Keith is a stickler for safety regulations. He kept his hard-hat on at all times for the construction cavorting.

Then, as if to prove he, too, had something to offer the ladies, Matt removed his shirt.

As did the A2 milk sponsor guy who turned up to shake some milkshakes (and his rippling physique). I am sure this wasn’t just a bit of gratuitous nudity rather an opportunity to show the kids at home what a diet high in calcium can do for your body.

El’ise seemed to have a one-track mind this week because she was also enthusing to all who would listen how her powder room (that’s a fancy name for spare toilet) was going to be “super sexy”.

That isn’t a description that I would generally associate with the lav.

In between all the half-naked blokes parading about the Oslo work site and talk of saucy bathroom fixtures, there was the obligatory dose of tears and tantrums from Tess.

The Cairns couple have fallen behind (again) prompting all and sundry to point out where they are going wrong.

When Tess heard that host Scotty Cam would be paying them another visit to lay down the law about their overspending on tradespeople, Tess did a runner.

If she had stayed to hear Scotty’s latest lecture, she would have heard how she and Luke had spent $25,000 more than the other four teams on tradespeople.

That’s a lot when you consider Deb and Andy and Mitch and Mark have no building qualifications while Luke is a carpenter by trade.

But Tess wasn’t having a bar of it.

“I am not a child,” she moaned.

“We are just defeated, deflated and over it! What’s the point?

“We are cutting back big time and I feel like we have done a lot to try and get here to where we are now, and we are constantly reminded of the negative.”

As she attempted to flee the set, she tearfully told a producer the toll that the show is taking on her personal life. She was sleep-deprived, strung-out and on the brink of walking out.

“This is destroying us… Luke and I hate each other. We just fight all the time. I don’t like what this is doing to us,” she protested.

“I mentally don’t think I could keep going but he is like a cane toad. They just don’t die.”

Even laid-back Luke, aka Mr Toad, admitted the experience on the show was pushing them to breaking point.

“We are newlyweds and we are having the worst time of our life,” he said, before throwing his arms around a sobbing Tess.

“This is not the ideal honeymoon situation. The constant fighting. It’s crap. It’s really crap. But it’s unique and we are unique sorts of people.”

Tess and Luke revealed that they were beginning to suspect the producers were hoping that they wouldn’t finish their house, thereby securing ratings-grabbing drama from their humiliating failure.

If that’s the case, it’s hard to imagine why they would have allowed Keith and his fellow foreman Dan to bring a team of people in to help the down-and-out Cairns couple get back in the game.

The free labour came on the back of Keith doing some work for them last week. And Dan has also lent a hand to the equally cash-strapped Matt and El’ise.

The helping hands that were being offered to the two teams didn’t go unnoticed by eagle-eyed Mark.

He pointed out that the added assistance being given to the two teams who hadn’t budgeted as well as everyone else seemed hardly fair.

“It’s interesting that extra resources are being put into house two. I am not sure how that works. Is that fair? Probably not,” Mark pointed out.

Despite Mitch and Mark’s opposition to the added assistance and the ongoing tension between the boys and their neighbours after spa-gate, the pair stepped up to help Tess and Luke in their hour of need (again).

They were probably buoyed by their triumph in this week’s challenge which saw their party house chosen to grace the cover of a real estate magazine.

So, when Tess offered to exchange a $2000 Freedom Furniture voucher for some free labour from the boys’ plasterers, they were open to the idea.

Even though, at this late stage of the game, Mitch and Mark don’t need a lot more furniture for an already cluttered abode, they agreed grudgingly to the trade.

And so, the Cairns cane toad and his missus live to fight (and plaster) another day.
